My ZeroNet-for-airlines idea from 

http://localhost:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1518637483_1KuwwnkAtVrfnyhv8pyGRxLqzNZbEkJt2u/Preparing+a+presentation+of+Zeronet+What+should+I+show

The core of the idea is that ZeroNet server has optional configuration for dividing IP-addresses to clusters and the optional settings describe the rules about the traffic between the IP-address clusters. That way all passengers on a flying airliner can have regular, free, access to the ZeroNet server, but all IP-addresses that are not onboard the flying airliner, are treated so that only zite updates are exchanged between the IP-addresses on board the flying plane and IP-addesses off the flying plane. The same with cruise ships and private yachts. 

The beauty of the ZeroNet Bittorrent nature is that huge planes like the Airbus 380
https://archive.is/gg2Az
need only one of its ZeroNet servers to be configured to have access to off-plane internet. The rest of the scaling can be done by just adding ZeroNet servers as if the extra servers were running on passenger computers. The purpose of the extra servers is only to boost the local zite seeding and to act as a cache for the updates that will be loaded off-plane in the background.

The same functionality will be needed on the flight to Mars, except that the delays between a spacecraft and "Earth station" will be minutes, not fractions of a second. So, it would be wise to design routing algorithms so that they can handle that kind of delays.

My native language is Estonian. I have found the following dictionaries very useful:

The highest quality dictionary that has the best English grammar book that I've ever seen in my whole life is:

The grammar book link is hard to notice, but this English grammar book has REALLY HIGH QUALITY:

Unfortunately the sound clip playing of TheFreeDictionary does not work on Linux. If I remember it correctly, I could be mistaken, it uses Adobe Flash. For that reason I use the following dictionary for pronunciation sound clips:
http://dictionary.cambridge.org/pronunciation/english/

I find the following dictionary very useful for finding out the exact spelling of Russian words that I have herd from videos: 
https://en.bab.la/dictionary/russian-english/
Unfortunately it does not always give the English translation of the word, so I sometimes manually copy-paste the word from that dictionary to some other dictionary.

Obviously the various built-in spellcheckers are a blessing :-D
